conclusion: In the given image, the shadows (A, C for the clock; B for the egg; D for the remote) are cast behind the respective objects relative to the viewer's perspective.
Shadow A is above shadow C, both cast by the clock.

premise: Shadow A is above shadow C, both cast by the clock.
conclusion: The clock is elevated and the light is hitting it from above and in front.
The light source is likely somewhat elevated and in front of the objects.

premise: The shadows are generally cast in a direction away from the viewer.
conclusion: The light source is towards the viewer's side of the objects.
Shadows are cast in the direction opposite to the light source.
If the light source is in front of an object (from the viewer's perspective), the shadow will be behind the object.
If the light source is behind an object, the shadow will be in front of the object (towards the viewer).
If the light source is to the left of an object, the shadow will be to the right.
If the light source is to the right of an object, the shadow will be to the left.
The size of the shadow depends on the distance of the object from the surface the shadow is cast on, the distance of the light source from the object, and the angle of the light rays.
A light source closer to the object casts a larger, more diffuse shadow (depending on source size). A light source further away casts a smaller, sharper shadow.
A light source low to the ground casts a long shadow. A light source high above casts a short shadow.

premise: The light source moves from being in front to being behind the objects, and also moves to the left.
conclusion: The shadows will be cast in front of the objects, towards the viewer, and to the right.

premise: The light source moves 'back' while staying at a similar height above the ground, or moving lower.
conclusion: The angle of the light rays hitting the ground becomes shallower, producing a longer shadow.

premise: The shadow of the alarm clock (which was represented by A and C) will shift to a position in front of the clock and to its right.
conclusion: The resulting shadow will likely be longer than the original shadows A and C.
